Mrs and Mrs Vidal.

The Vidals.

A slight movement beside her was what pulled her from her thoughts and she looked to her side to see Agatha watching her closely, her fingers flexing against her thigh.

“Rio and I will tidy up. You all go through.”

She stood from her seat and already began to reach for plates, but Billy stood quickly too as if to help, “Let me!”

“No,” Agatha said sharply, and Billy winced.

“Geez, Agatha. Relax. We’ll leave you alone to talk to your girl. But if you goddamn propose without me here I will kill you. That’s social media gold.”

Agatha huffed but ran a hand through her hair as everyone began to move and Rio stood to continue piling the dishes up.

“Leave it,” Agatha said in a voice much softer than the one she’d just used on Billy.

Rio glanced up at her and saw in Agatha’s eyes that she looked concerned. A gentle touch to her elbow told her that Alice had just left the room and they were now alone.

“I just wanted to be clear earlier. I meant that-…”

Agatha bit down on her lip and sank back down to her chair, sitting sideways on it and gazing up at Rio with that same look, “I shouldn’t have announced that I’d take your name.”

“No,” Rio said quickly, suddenly concerned that Agatha was taking it back. “I, uh,” but Agatha had taken her hands from where she was sitting and was looking up at her with that same look of concern and she forgot what she was about to say.

“Harkness has never meant much to me, with my mother… but your family, you being my family…”

Rio felt her mouth go dry again and she cleared her throat, unsure what to even say to this.

“I’m going to ask Jen to stop talking about it.”

Rio could only nod at this, her brow furrowing just a little as she let Agatha hold her hands.

Agatha was shutting it down. Shutting her down. But she couldn’t argue it. They weren’t ready to talk about marriage. Were they?

So she continued to nod even as Agatha stood slowly and took one of her hands to cup Rio’s cheek and stop her movements. “Go get comfortable and I’ll bring the wine.”

Rio nodded again and then before Agatha could lean in to kiss her she pulled away and went to find a seat in the living room.

The corner of the large couch was available closest to the Christmas tree that dominated the bay window.

So Rio sat there, curling her legs up beneath herself and waiting for Agatha to come back through. Alice gave her a soft smile and raised her brows in question but Rio just shook her head slightly and went back to chewing on her lip.

Five minutes later, when the conversation in the room had moved onto Jen and Alice’s next big holiday, Agatha finally appeared.

She carried with her two bottles of red and placed them on the coffee table before she went to take a seat by Rio, moving to take her legs up and sit beneath them. The hand that rested on Rio’s upper thigh was wearing her watch and Rio glanced down at the sight, counting the seconds as they ticked by and watching the way Agatha’s fingers tapped at her thigh.

She felt an odd mixture of completely thrown and totally comforted. Agatha had considered marrying her, clearly even before her friends had decided to bet on it and Lilia had drawn cards, but it wasn’t something she’d ever discussed with her.

And Rio, hadn’t really ever entertained the idea.

Agatha had been married before and been so burned by it that she’d never considered that she’d want to again. And Rio had never considered herself to be someone who would get married. Her job for one thing made dating something that had to be deprioritised and in the back of her mind she’d always thought well who would want to marry an old, retired hooker?.

But Rio had no problem with marriage. Had no real issue with being legally and publicly bound to somebody else.

To Agatha.

As her mind drifted to matching rings and the image of Agatha in white, with eyes only for her, she got a fright when Jen announced her name loudly and felt the room turn to look at her expectantly.

“What? I was…”

“Thinking about your girl, yes we know. Practically drooling.”

Rio frowned and surreptitiously wiped at her mouth, just in case.

“I was just saying that despite our issues it’s actually quite sweet to see you having tamed the beast.”

Rio raised her brows at this and a large smile cracked her features as she turned to look at the beast in question, seeing her scowl.

“Beast is a bit strong,” Rio cooed as she raised a hand to brush two fingers along Agatha’s cheek. The hand on her thigh squeezed a little but Agatha only had eyes for Jen and she continued to scowl, “And with what poor Alice has to put up with? Rich, Jen. Very rich.”

Jen just laughed and threw her hand out at Agatha as if to bat her away but the conversation turned then to more inane chat; half the room half a sleep and the other half not far behind.

It wasn’t long later that Rio found herself curled up beside her beast in bed, pressing close into her and breathing in the her girlfriend’s familiar perfume.

“Thank you for putting up with them today.”

The whisper was so soft, and Rio was so tired, that she almost missed it. But it came with such gravity that she forced herself to focus in, pushing back to blink at Agatha.

“I didn’t put up with them. I enjoyed them.”

Agatha kept silent for a few seconds before she spoke again, “I think they all like you more than they like me.”

“Impossible,” Rio breathed as she moved to press a soft kiss to Agatha’s jaw.

Agatha just hummed softly as Rio spoke again, stifling a yawn, “Go to sleep.”

Agatha didn’t protest this and turned more towards Rio, brushing her lips at her temple as she settled.

Sleep took them both slowly, then all at once. And their first Christmas Day ended in each other’s arms, Rio dreaming of soft white silk and Agatha dreaming of the same.

The next morning came around all too quickly for Rio’s liking. But she wasn’t woken by a familiar touch of hands or lips but instead by a gentle but unknown hand that shook her shoulder where she slept in the middle of the bed, starfished out like she’d been washed ashore.

“Rio. Rio, wake up. Agatha needs you.”

Rio groaned quietly, words not quite making sense in the hazy morning light as she rubbed at her eyes.

“Rio.”

Huffing a soft breath, Rio turned slowly to blink up at Lilia Calderu, concerned in her shawls at the edge of the bed.

“Agatha needs you,” she repeated more firmly this time.

The words hit this time. Rio frowned deeply and began to shuffle inelegantly from under the blankets and covers, sliding to the edge of the bed beside Lilia, “What’s wrong? Is she okay?”

“You’ll see.”

Rio followed Lilia down with the thickness of sleep still settled in her bones and the panic of Agatha’s unknown plight settled in her chest.

But she didn’t need to wait long to hear what could be the cause of it.

Jen.

As they reached the first landing, Rio could hear Jen’s voice, distorted and muffled through the walls and ceilings, but distinct for its volume.

“Shit.”

“The ties that bind,” Lilia said quietly.

Rio slipped past Lilia and ran the rest of the way, following the voice through to Agatha’s office where she barged in to a scene already in full swing.

“You can’t fucking do this!” Jen was screaming.

Alice was beside her, half holding her arms out to guard her and half to stop her from launching at Agatha, who stood back against her desk, watching Jen with an unreadable expression.

Other than the shouting, the first thing she noticed was that she was the only one not dressed for the day. Though judging by Billy’s messy hair and hangdog expression it looked like he too had been dragged out of bed.

But blue eyes had fallen to her as she’d entered the room and Rio noticed Agatha’s throat bob as she gulped and adjusted her position against the desk.

“What’s going on? What’s happened?”

Rio moved quickly to Agatha’s side, keeping her eyes on her girlfriend and her back to the still furious Jen.

“She’s sold my fucking company!”

Rio’s hand froze in midair where she’d raised her fingers to Agatha’s cheek and she looked completely taken aback as she turned to catch sight of Jen, watching her with a deep frown.

“I didn’t. Listen to me. I’ve done everything and sorted it all so all you need to do-…”

“You fucking ruthless bitch. How could you? How did you even-…?”

But Jen’s words died on her tongue and she suddenly looked like she’d seen a ghost, her gaze sweeping suddenly across to Billy.

“You son of a bitch. You gave her my financials.”

Rio’s stomach dropped at the sight of the boy cowering up against the bookshelf, looking paler than she’d ever seen him and she made a move to go to him but Agatha had grabbed her wrist and shook her head no.

“I-… I-…”

“You’re fucking fired you little traitor.”

“Jen,” Alice said urgently, her hovering hands now working their way to Jen’s arms, “Jen. Listen to Agatha. What’s she’s saying makes-…”

“No!” Jen screamed, winding her arms around to knock her wife’s hands off of her, “No. I have worked and worked for this-…”

“You fucked yourself when you went into business with her,” Agatha explained, her voice steady but her lip quivering ever so slightly, for only Rio to notice.

“I’m just unfucking it for you.”

“You cannot sell my company.”

“I know. You need to do it. You need to sign the papers.”

Jen released a cry that was somewhere between a scream and a yell and threw her hands up again, making as if to strangle Agatha but not moving from where she stood.

“I am trying to protect you.”

“You are trying to be in control! Trying to be the big saviour! The big ‘I am’!”

Agatha took in a slow breath and shifted where she stood, “Jennifer. If you don’t sell you will be ruined.”

Jen just scoffed and shook her head in disgust. “I see it now. I see why she cheated and why you had to pay to get someone to be with you. Agatha Harkness has power over everyone. But not me. You have no power over me! Fuck you and fuck your contract.”

“Jen,” Alice pleaded even as Rio stepped in front of Agatha and was pulled back by the same hand still on her wrist.

“No. Fuck this. Fuck her.”

Jen stormed from the room then, leaving a shocked silence behind her and an unsure, torn Alice who turned to look at Agatha. “She didn’t mean-…”

“It’s okay,” Agatha said with none of her usual verve. “Go after her.”

Alice turned on her heel and left.

Rio’s first concern was for Agatha and she turned around to see that blue eyes had filled with tears and her face was slowly, painfully crumbling in on itself. But Agatha pushed her away as she went to cradle her cheeks and turned from her to take a seat at her desk.

“I’m fine. Take Billy. I have work to do.”

“Agatha,” Rio insisted with a frown, moving around to her but a hand was held up and Agatha kept her gaze away from Rio, staring intently at her laptop instead.

“Please, Rio.”

Hesitating, and reluctant, Rio turned away from the devastated woman at her desk and moved instead to Billy. She took his hand gently and guided the shell-shocked man from the room, meeting Lilia in the hall looking stern.

“Tea,” Lilia said quickly, “Tea with honey. You’re in shock.”

Rio nodded and guided Billy to the kitchen to fetch them all just that.

The rest of the house was still and silent and Rio knew that Jen and Alice had disappeared into the cold day. Her mind was going a mile a minute as she poured the hot tea out. She’d caught half the story. Half the accusations. But she didn’t understand anything past Agatha trying to sell Jen’s company and the inevitable witch that was always at the centre of everything: Wanda.

She forced herself to gulp down her still too-hot tea before she eventually went back to Agatha’s office to seek out the devastated woman holed up in there.

She didn’t knock when she entered, having got used to being allowed in whenever she wanted to see Agatha, talk to her, be near her.

But this time she wasn’t welcomed in.

“It’s fine, Rio. I have things to do.”

“No,” Rio insisted softly, already moving around to Agatha’s side of the desk and turning her chair to look down at her properly.

“Tell me. What just happened?”

Agatha sighed heavily and closed her eyes as she gathered herself. Her posture had been rigid when Rio walked in but now her shoulders slumped and she rubbed at her eyes in frustration.

“Jen fucked herself when she took that bitch’s money. I don’t know why she did it. The promise of connections, I don’t know. Wanda got into her head and I told her not to I told her-…”

She trailed off and sighed as she raised her gaze to Rio’s concerned face.

“She holds a minority stake in the company. But it’s enough to cause Jen a hell of a lot of issues when-…”

She stopped herself and shook her head slightly, “Wanda is in bed with a lot of bad people. When it comes out… when I make sure it comes out… everyone that’s connected to her will be fucked too. So I’ve found Jen a buyer. Negotiated a good deal. Done everything I needed to ensure that all she needs to do is sign on the dotted line and she can slip away from this all without losing everything. If I’ve played it right, and I know I have, she’ll be able to start again. No ties to Wanda. Everything intact.”

As Agatha spoke Rio ached for the weight that the woman before her must have been carrying on her shoulders - of the pains she’d gone through to protect not only Rio but Jen and by extension Alice too. And as she ruminated on this she grew impossibly more angry at Jen for having thrown it back in her face, for having slapped Agatha with her accusations earlier, for having been so cruel and demeaning.

“Agatha,” Rio said softly, reaching to caress her cheek and watching as Agatha closed her eyes and leant into her touch.

But how could she possibly tell this woman how incredible she was. How much she loved her. How much she wanted to protect her from everything she was so stubbornly and vehemently taking on herself?

So she moved closer and Agatha’s eyes flickered open, her hands seeking the backs of Rio’s knees to knock them in and pull her into her lap. Rio followed her and settled on top of her, cradling her face gently in her hands. “I love you. So much. None of what Jen said-…”

“I know,” Agatha murmured softly, her hands squeezing gently at Rio’s hips as she tugged her closer.

“What you’re doing for me… for your friends…”

“I know,” Agatha said again, her gaze now drifting to Rio’s lips even as she continued to look tired, defeated.

“Agatha,” Rio insisted, worried that Agatha wasn’t really listening or that she didn’t believe what she was trying to say.

“I know,” Agatha said again, shaking her head as she leant up to brush her lips over Rio’s, seeking comfort from having her so close.

Rio sighed quietly but pressed her lips back to Agatha’s with a frown still across her features. “I want you to listen. I want you to know that I love-…”

Agatha shook her head a little and kissed Rio again, pulling her impossibly closer.

“Marry me. Be mine. Marry me.”

Rio pulled back slowly, blinking down at Agatha stupidly, watching as those blue eyes darted about her own face, watching Rio’s reaction closely.

“Agatha,” Rio murmured solemnly, unsure she’d heard correctly or if Agatha were simply teasing her, trying to avoid the reassurance that Rio was trying desperately to give.

But Agatha only held her firmly, her fingers tight against her hips and her eyes unwavering as they looked into Rio’s.

“Marry me.”

“I-…”

Agatha shook her head again, her gaze suddenly desperate as she held Rio so tightly she knew she’d have finger marks on her later. “Please. Please. Marry me.”

Rio’s reaction, her heart suddenly so full, was to laugh. Her cheeks flushing a soft pink as the reality of what was happening slowly sunk in.

“Okay.”

Agatha’s frown of concern, her tense features and worried eyes seemed to disappear then, her whole body relaxing and her hold on Rio softening just slightly as she gazed up at her with slight surprise. “Okay?”

Rio laughed again, a proper, true belly laugh as she began to grin, “Yes. Yes! I’ll marry you.”

Rio’s laughter took a while to make it to Agatha’s face but when it did she caught it readily, and laughed too, capturing Rio’s own joy against her mouth as she pressed their lips together and kissed her through it.

By the time they pulled apart all the stress and pain from the morning was forgotten and Agatha was grinning against Rio’s lips, pressing herself as close as physically possible.

“Fucking Lilia and her fucking cards. I wanted to do it when all this was over. When we could just… be.”

Rio hummed in amusement and kissed Agatha quickly, as if her mouth had some sort of gravitational pull and she weren’t able to keep from it for long, “So you did plan on proposing soon? You’re not just… doing it because Lilia predicted you would?”

“I hate being told what to do.”

“Only sometimes.”

Agatha huffed quietly and kissed Rio again, her hands darting to her lower back, “I'll get you a ring. The biggest, most expensive one. Whatever you want.”

“I don’t care about that. I just want you.”

In their little bubble, the two of them remained for another hour or so, before Agatha’s hands started to roam and Rio was incapable of denying her now fiancée. They fucked slowly, languidly in the chair, against the desk, on the floor, and for the sake of Lilia and a still distraught Billy down the hall, Rio managed to control her own volume and made a point to control Agatha’s too.

By the time they were out of breath, with a light sheen of sweat against their bodies, on the floor beside Agatha’s large oak desk, Rio couldn’t think of a time when she’d been happier.

At some point between the first and third location, Agatha had moved Rio’s new ring to her left hand as a symbolic gesture that made Rio’s heart sing and her pulse race even more than it already was.

But the reality was that Billy was nearby and needed support and Agatha would eventually have to face up to whatever Jen still had left to give her when she eventually returned - if she ever did.

And so they reluctantly agreed to go their separate ways: Agatha to find Billy and Lilia and Rio to shower and change.

By the time Rio came back down to the living room her new position as a fiancée had settled in and she toyed with the ring now on her left hand ring finger.

Billy was the first to greet her with a small smile but a large hug and a whispered, “I’m so happy for you.”

Lilia was quick to offer her congratulations not long after but something told Rio that she hadn’t needed to be told by Agatha and that she’d already known. Spooky bitch.

And finally, Agatha drew up the rear, pulling Rio into a warm and familiar hug as she whispered, “Billy was crying and this news was the only thing that’s shut him up.”

Rio’s heart clenched at this confession and she pulled from Agatha to turn back to the boy, offering him her hand, “Jen will come around.”

“She won’t.”

Agatha scoffed and hardened as she went to sit back on the couch. “She will if she knows what’s good for her.”

Rio sighed quietly and went to sit beside Agatha, keeping her gaze on Billy. “Alice will talk her down.”

But Billy didn’t look reassured and Rio spent the majority of the rest of the day trying to distract him whilst desperately wanting to be alone with Agatha to languish in their shared joy.

Around 10pm, Rio was sprawled on the floor by the fire, leaning over a 1,000 piece jigsaw with Billy, diligently placing pieces to create the frame for what would eventually be a picture of the colosseum.

Agatha was working on her laptop on the couch, her glasses perched on her nose and her eyes darting every so often to watch Rio as she concentrated on the task at hand.

Lilia was engrossed in a book on tarot, unaware of her surroundings as she twirled a grey curl between her fingers.

But they all looked up at the sound of the front door opening and Rio sat immediately to move to Agatha’s side, watching as a frowning Alice and then a sheepish Jen walked in the room.

“Hey,” Rio said cautiously, her eyes flickering from Alice to Jen and back again.

Alice smiled tightly but had turned to nudge her wife more into the room and Rio watched as a very stiff and uncomfortable Jen moved a few steps in, her body turned to Agatha but her eyes looking anywhere but.

“What I said earlier. I’m sorry for it.”

Rio raised her brows in surprise at this and glanced to her side as Agatha moved to push the laptop from her lap and to the couch beside her.

“I know you were trying to help. And I know I shouldn’t have gone into business with Wanda in the first place.”

Agatha remained silent.

“And…” Jen shifted where she stood and Alice went to take her hand, “And if you can, I’d like you to still facilitate the sale.”

“Well fuck, Jen, sound more grateful than that.”

“Agatha,” Rio warned softly but turned to see Agatha smirking slightly, her demeanour teasing rather than cruel.

“I have conditions,” Jen said suddenly, only willing to give so much.

“Firstly, you have to hire Billy back. He’s obsessed with you and I can’t trust him not to go running to you with whatever you ask him for again.”

Rio looked over at Billy who looked suddenly pale again and saw that he was toying with a piece of the puzzle nervously.

“Secondly, when I set up my next company. And I will. You are going to fund it. Minority stakes, obviously. But no more of this ‘I don’t fund personal vanity projects’ shit anymore. You’re funding it.”

Agatha shifted a little.

“Thirdly, I want you to destroy her.”

At this, Agatha released a bark of a laugh and Rio raised her brows in surprise.

“The third thing is easy. The other two…”

Jen rolled her eyes at this and was about to say something when Alice spoke up. “Wait.”

She moved closer and narrowed her eyes at the sight of Rio’s left hand on Agatha’s thigh.

“Why is your ring on your…?”

Everyone in the room turned to look at the ring in question and Rio smirked a little as she caught Agatha’s gaze.

“You bitch. I told you to wait. That would have killed on the gram.”

But Jen’s protests were drowned out by the scream that Alice released as she ran at the two horrified women on the couch.

Chapter End Notes

It’s been a long time coming but we’re meeting Tony properly next up

The Truth Will Set You Free

Chapter Summary

A snapshot of life after an engagement. A journey to Manhattan. A revelation.

Chapter Notes

This was initially part of a much larger whole but I’ve chopped it out because … well … you’ll see how it ends

Trust more to come

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The unassuming envelope lay in wait on the bedside table for the sleeping woman in the plush bed of the large townhouse in Washington D.C.

It had been placed there by another hand not an hour ago, by the other woman who usually occupied the California king beside her sleeping partner.

But patient this envelope was not, and as the morning sun began to hit its peak, an uninvited breeze blew through the opened window and knocked the envelope on its back.

The material was thick and expensive and the subsequent thwack on the oak side table was enough to jostle the sleeping woman from her dreams.

Rio woke with a groan and rubbed at her eyes, blinking into the morning sun to see that she was once again alone.

Since the day they’d become engaged Rio had been seeing progressively less and less of her new fiancée, and it wasn’t unusual for her to fall into bed alone and wake up just the same.

Agatha was now in the thick of campaign planning and rarely spent a night at home anymore. She’d holed herself up in a small office in the depths of the Capitol building, keeping Billy up and working until all hours of the morning to pore over Stark’s commitments, his stances, his speeches.

And Rio, she’d pined only for the first few days, making the mistake of watching a pot and expecting it to boil. But after a week or so of expecting Agatha to suddenly have a freer schedule, she’d begun to fill her own.

Rio now had interviews lined up, some job offers thrown her way that she debated on and sifted through, a new team she was slowly building a rapport with, and a packed diary of teaching classes at the local gym and travelling back and forth to New York - something she sometimes managed to tie in with Agatha’s visits so they at least had the length of a car ride to be together (though often with Billy, much to Agatha’s annoyance).

It wasn’t uncommon for Rio to wake up a few nights a week in the early hours of the morning with Agatha draped over her and snoring softly in her ear. And she’d wake up a few hours later and with the ghost of Agatha’s warm body still lingering but her fiancée gone.

They’d fallen into the kind of intimacy that only comes when one is never available and the other is often absent. They caught snippets of time together, snapshots of evenings, weekends, days. Agatha was often tired and Rio was often lonely.

Rio opened the envelope and found an invitation printed on thick red card.

——

You Are Cordially Invited to a Fundraising Reception and Auction in Support of Senator Tony Stark

Please join us for an evening of community, conversation, and commitment to building a stronger future. This special event will include a live and silent auction featuring exclusive items and experiences, with all proceeds benefiting the campaign of Tony Stark, (R-NY).

Date: Saturday, February 23rd 
Time: 8pm – Midnight
 Location:  The Glasshouse,
660 12th Avenue,
New York City.

Suggested Contribution Levels:
* $2,000 – Supporter
* $10,000 – Advocate
* $50,000 – Hero

RSVP by February 10th to Billy Kaplan at 555-965-7971 or [email protected]
Online contributions and registration available at: ironman.com

We look forward to your support and to sharing this important evening with you.

Warm regards,   Billy Kaplan, Executive Assistant  Stark for President: Power. Responsibility. Progress.

 

Paid for by Stark for President. Contributions are not tax-deductible. Please consult local election laws regarding contribution limits and disclosures.

——

Rio rolled her eyes at the suggestion that anyone donating $50,000 to Stark could be considered a ‘Hero’.

The one benefit of seeing less of Agatha was that discussions, and fights, about Tony’s run were fewer and far between. Only once since Christmas had they fallen out after a particularly egregious (to Rio) speech from Stark at the Mexican border where he was speaking to reporters when a man seeking refuge on American soil had been detained before the cameras.

Agatha had been present for the whole thing and after it had been televised had Rio called her to give her what for.

“I want you to pull out. Quit.”

“Honey…”

“Don’t ‘honey’ me, Agatha. I saw what he said to that man as he was being wrestled to the ground: ‘Land of the free, home of the documented, my friend’.” Rio immigrated Stark’s masculine vibrato. “He’s a cunt and you should know better.”

“We’ve discussed this-…”

“Yes, as you keep saying but actually all you’ve done is told me you have to do it and I just don’t think that’s true anymore. It’s not good enough for me.”

Agatha had remained silent for a while and Rio could practically hear her thoughts swirling, “It doesn’t have to be good enough for you. It just is what it is.”

“You can’t even argue it! You can’t even defend-…!”

“Rio, Stark is all bluster. He’s an arrogant asshole with an inflated ego who is appealing to the lowest-…”

“And you’re the one trying to make him King.”

An article had been published in The Times not a week prior titled: ‘Agatha Harkness: King Maker’ detailing Agatha’s career thus far and focusing on her key role in the Stark Campaign that was thundering ahead of every other candidate in the opinion polls.

Agatha had not been pleased but Rio had been incandescent.

“His politics aren’t the same as his voters. He’s appealing to-…”

“I don’t care who he’s appealing to. I care that you’re standing by and supporting him as he spews all this bullshit that actually impacts peoples lives.”

“I’m back tomorrow night. Can we discuss it then?”

When they hung up they didn’t speak again until Agatha had arrived through the front door just after midnight looking tired and resigned.

Rio had gone easier on her than she meant to because of this. But they’d stayed up until 3am debating back and forth, arguing the point that Rio saw so clearly and that Agatha refused to back down on: Agatha had to quit.

The argument had been long and cyclical, with Rio bringing up the same facts over and over again: they were engaged, they were public, she didn’t care who knew about her past, and they both had enough friends and money that they would be fine, protected.

But Agatha was insistent that for now, at least, she continue to push Stark towards the White House.

And so the argument ended like it always did; pausing for a brief reprieve until the next time.

Rio hadn’t expected to be invited to this particular campaign fundraiser but knew Agatha had been working on it for a while now. Billy had clearly taken it upon himself to invite Rio specifically, thinking she deserved an invitation as more than just Agatha’s plus one, and whilst she was flattered that he’d gone to the effort it hadn’t exactly filled her with joy.

By the time she was showered and dressed for the day, she was feeling a little more relaxed about it, at least relaxed enough to discuss it with Agatha without getting mad.

9:03am
Rio Vidal: I got Billy’s invite. Does he just want someone sane to talk to amongst the republicans or did you sanction my being on the guest list?

9:07am
Agatha Harkness: I requested it.

9:11am
Rio Vidal: That so?

9:13am
Agatha Harkness: Every donation counts.

9:15am
Rio Vidal: Not funny.

9:27am
Agatha Harkness: Pepper has been dying to meet you and I’d like you there with me.

9:34am
Rio Vidal: Could have asked the old fashioned way.

10:15am
Agatha Harkness: Wasn’t waking up to a mysterious envelope kind of sexy?

10:18am
Rio Vidal: Not when it contains the words ‘Stark for President’

10:34am
Agatha Harkness: Point taken. Will you come?

10:42am
Rio Vidal: Don’t I always

10:43am
Agatha Harkness: I make sure of it. Speaking of: I should be home earlier tonight and I’ve missed you…

10:57am
Rio Vidal: Then make sure you are and you can show me exactly how much you’ve missed me.

Rio smirked to herself as she sent the last text off knowing that Agatha would make sure she was home early and make sure she knew she was missed.

She called Natasha then, trying still to force something that had never had to be forced before. Natasha had been distant since she’d left for Washington and had barely spoken to her since then. Rio had called every day, had text when Natasha wouldn’t pick up, and had even gone to her empty apartment to see her whenever she was back in the city. But either Natasha was telling the truth and she genuinely was very busy or she simply didn’t want to see Rio.

The latter option was so untenable to Rio that she didn’t often let herself think on it and instead, rightly or wrongly, continued to contact Natasha whenever she could.

Agatha’s belief that Natasha was in love with her had settled itself like a virus in Rio’s blood stream, infecting every part of her slowly but insidiously turning her mind to what could be the reality: Agatha was right, Natasha was in love with her.

But she’d not asked her. Never brought it up. Even when she did manage to get Natasha on the phone she was short, clipped, monosyllabic.

The day the invitation came through was no different.

“Hey.”

“Hey.”

“How are you? I’ve been trying to call the past few days.”

“Yeah, I’ve been busy.”

“Too busy to text or call me back?”

“Evidently.”

“Nat. Talk to me.”

“Rio, I don’t have a lot of time. What is it?”

Rio only sighed and rubbed the back of her neck.

“Fine. If you want to be this way then… I’ll be back in the city the weekend of the 23rd. I’m coming to stay on the Friday. If you don’t show up then fine. I’m not chasing anymore. So if you’re not there I’ll have my answer.”

“I’ll be home.”

“Good. I want to talk to you properly.”

“I look forward to it.”

“Shut up. I’ll call you tomorrow.”

“Cuídate, Rio.” Look after yourself, Rio

With that, Rio had her last proper conversation with Natasha until their inevitable chat when she arrived at her apartment.

“Consider it,” Agatha said with a slight frown, watching Rio closely for any sign her request might be the cause of another, actual, argument.

“It’s just ridiculous. I go back and forth to the gym and the park and that’s about it.”

“Exactly. A pattern. An easy to pick up-…”

“Then you need to teach, not scare him.”

“No, I’m going straight from Nat’s to see the team.”

“Not ‘breaking’. Telling. I’m telling her about the engagement, yes.”

“Maybe I should get you that security sooner rather than later.”

A brilliant, round diamond on a slim gold band. It was simple, and beautiful, and Agatha had spent a small fortune on it, much to Rio’s horror. But she loved it and was slowly getting used to holding the GDP of a small European country on her finger.

On the other hand, Agatha had said she didn’t care much about what ring she got and that Rio could buy her one, or not, and she’d be just as happy whatever. But Rio had a sneaking suspicion it was because Agatha hadn’t wanted her to spend as much as she had on Rio’s ring. So she spent weeks going from shop to shop in search of the perfect ring for her perfect Agatha. Eventually, after a lot of back and forth and several frantic calls to Alice, she’d found the ring she thought would suit Agatha best. It was a triple cushion-cut diamond ring on a thicker band than her own: classic, elegant, beautiful.

She’d waited up until 2am to give it to Agatha, straight off a full day of meetings and calls, and had a panic attack when Agatha had cried at the sight of it.

But once she’d calmed down, once she’d curled up around Rio in their shared bed with their shared rings, she had admitted that she loved it and that Rio’s effort to find her the perfect ring meant the world to her.

“No,” Rio agreed with a growing smile, “You bought it because you want everyone to know that you’re soon going to be a Vidal.”

“I know,” Agatha relented, her grin fading as she watched Rio. “Maybe tell her though if she’s-…”

But Rio interrupted quickly, because although Agatha had been trying her best to remain neutral about Natasha and her recent behaviour, she still wasn’t her biggest fan.

“Don’t. I’ll call you if I’m going to come home early.”

“I’m just saying,” Agatha started again but a little softer this time, “She’s being a bitch and… you deserve better than that.”

Rio released a slow breath that she didn’t know she’d been holding and leant her head against the backseat, watching Agatha with a small frown, “Maybe one day you’ll get on. Like me and Alice.”

Agatha scoffed loudly then and turned away, sliding her hand back down Rio’s legs to hold her calf, “Yeah. Over my dead body.”

“Hey. She’s family. So she’s your family too.”

Agatha scoffed again and turned to stare at Rio, “Family doesn’t try to get in family’s pants.”

“Nat has not tried to get into my pants,” Rio corrected, “Your theory is baseless and I’m going to tell her what you think tonight.”

“I’m sure that’ll go down well.”

Huffing again Rio raised her brows, “Well it’ll be incredibly embarrassing for me to ask my best friend of almost twenty years if she is in love with me.”

“You wouldn’t be asking if you didn’t think there were an outside chance that she might be.”

Blue eyes moved to Rio’s brown ones and Agatha leant back more in her seat, sliding down a little to get more comfortable.

“And if she says she is?”

Rio hadn’t expected Agatha to ask that. And she hadn’t expected her body to react in the way it did when she did. The sudden and dangerous urge to vomit came over her and she felt her palms get sweaty, as if she were about to go cliff diving or something. But no, this was scarier than that. Natasha being in love with her would be a cataclysmic event. It would be unthinkable, and so Rio hadn’t allowed herself to think past what might happen if she said yes.

“She won’t.”

But Agatha knew her better than that, knew her tells when she lied and knew her body’s reactions to almost everything. Her hand tightened around her calf and she reached her other up to rest across Rio’s thigh, squeezing her gently. “Honey, if she is?”

“Then,” Rio started slowly, focusing down on Agatha’s hand over her lower leg. “Then I’ll deal with it.”

Agatha nodded and kept her gaze on Rio’s face for a long time, though Rio was now avoiding her gaze, but soon looked away and returned both hands to Rio’s calves, tapping a random pattern there as she did.

“It wouldn’t change anything, you know,” Rio murmured quietly after a tense silence had descended on the car. “Not with us I mean.”

Agatha remained quiet and kept her gaze down on her own fingers as they continued to tap a slow pattern over Rio’s leg. “Hey.”

Reluctantly, Agatha turned back to Rio and watched her closely as Rio shuffled a little closer and raised her hand to Agatha’s cheek, “Are you worried about it?”

“No,” Agatha lied quickly.

“I’m marrying you. I want to marry you. You will be my wife. Mi esposa.” She dropped her hand to Agatha’s left and lifted it up to press a kiss over her ring, maintaining eye contact with Agatha the whole time as if this woman were her spiritual leader and Rio were a desperate congregant seeking salvation.

“I just want you and me on an island somewhere where no one can get to us and no one knows where we are.”

Agatha’s expression had turned from concerned to desperate and she turned her body more towards Rio, allowing her hand to be taken and kissed again. “Mi amor,” Rio whispered soothingly, letting her lips brush the back of Agatha’s hand “eso no es vida. That isn’t life. I want you here. With me. With everyone we love. Because that is life.”

Agatha’s frown deepened and her gaze fell from Rio again as Rio brought her hand back down to her lap, “Agatha.”

Rio shuffled until she was practically curled into Agatha’s lap, side on to her on the bench. “Finish this with Stark. Finish it now and we can disappear for a while. And when we come back we can start a proper life together. One where you’re not away all the time and where you’re not carrying this weight on your shoulders. It’s not healthy. It’s not necessary.”

Rio watched as this hypothetical reality washed over stoic features. The wave of potential for what could be if she’d just let go pulled at Agatha like a riptide and Rio saw in her eyes and ocean of pain that she had only just started to wade through, Agatha still keeping her at arms length when it came to her deep-rooted struggle.

“I have to do it,” Agatha said quietly, the bravado and bullishness not quite there anymore. “I have to.”

Rio frowned in confusion, a familiar feeling settling in her chest as the Agatha she had first met, the one who pushed and pulled, became the Agatha between her thighs, wearing her ring. “You don’t have to do anything.”

But Agatha wasn’t listening anymore and her fingers twisted in Rio’s belt loops, forcing Rio to shift closer as her gaze raised up, “We’ll be on that beach soon. I promise.”

But Rio didn’t want just a beach. She didn’t want Agatha alone on a tropical island if it came at the expense of her building walls that she was killing herself behind.

I don’t want the beach. I want you.

But she didn’t say it, didn’t push because she couldn’t spend the rest of the evening arguing with Agatha, making her see sense, making her agree. She had the length of a car journey. So instead she moved her hand to clutch her jaw, forcing it up so she could kiss her. It was firm, full of words unspoken and feelings uninhibited, but it was just a kiss.

As she pulled away she scanned over Agatha’s features whilst her eyes remained closed and she saw that same tiredness there that had been present for weeks now, months even. It made her feel small, ineffectual, useless.

Agatha wouldn’t let her help her. She wouldn’t let her in. But Rio continued to push for it. Determined to protect Agatha the way Agatha stubbornly protected her.

As her eyes scanned over her fiancée’s features Rio thought again about the wonder that was Agatha Harkness.

Agatha was tragically beautiful. Her Grecian profile, her bright eyes, her tumbling waves that contrasted so distinctly against the sharp lines of an elegant jaw, and defined cheekbones. She was Athena in a pantsuit.

A tired goddess carved from deep sorrow and adamantine resolve.

Rio shifted above Agatha, her hands moving to run down her neck until they found their place clutching at her collar and she leant in to press another soft kiss to the corner of her waiting lips.

“You’re so beautiful. How did I get so lucky?”

Agatha’s lips twitched at this and her eyes opened slowly, still with slight caution in her gaze as she moved her hands to trace just below Rio’s t-shirt.

“I’m the lucky one.”

Rio smiled against Agatha’s lips and kissed her again, lingering a little longer this time. “We’re both lucky.”

As Rio pulled back Agatha’s hands began to roam up her stomach, flexing her fingers across her ribs and skimming just below her bra.

“Jimmy,” Rio whispered quietly in warning, arching a brow down at her fiancée who had gone from cautious and concerned to keen and determined within the space of a second.

“It’s Agatha, actually,” Agatha teased with a growing smirk as she moved one hand up to press her fingers below the cup of Rio’s right breast.

Rio bit down on her lip and reached to hold Agatha’s hand in place there, preventing her from doing much more than squeezing her breast gently.

“Keep it in your pants, please.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but squeezed again before she slowly slipped her hand back down to a more respectable position against Rio’s waist.

“It’s egregious that you won’t let me grope you in my own car.”

“Oh is it?” Rio grinned widely at this, having had this discussion many times in this exact position in the back of Agatha’s sedan.

“Yes. Especially given I haven’t seen your boobs in five days.”

“Five?” Rio asked with an even wider grin, her hands moving up to cover her own breasts as if they were on show now and the tally of days had slipped back to zero.

“That can’t be right.”

“It is, actually,” Agatha continued as if they were discussing something as mundane as the weather. “It was Monday morning when I got up for work. Your tank had slipped in your sleep and I got a glimpse. Nothing more exciting than that.”

Agatha’s serious expression melted before Rio’s narrowed eyes and she pouted dramatically, her fingers lightly scraping at Rio’s stomach as if she’d been denied something special, something precious.

“It won’t work.”

“You’re being cruel.”

“I am respecting Jimmy.”

“And I am asking you to respect me. My needs.”

In spite of herself Rio found herself smiling at this, once again flummoxed by the hold Agatha had on her, how she could go from fragile and mythical to seductive and playful in the space of mere seconds.

The pout disappeared immediately.

“There you go, maniac.”

“That was worse than no boobs. Tease.”

“Fiancée,” Agatha corrected quickly but with a smirk as she shifted to remain as close to Rio as possible even with her now off of her lap. “We all have to have hobbies.”

Rio rolled her eyes again but moved her hand to Agatha’s cheek and watched as her head turned to kiss her palm. “After the fundraiser tomorrow I promise you unlimited access to my boobs.”

“Finally,” Agatha grumbled as she leant in to steal a quick kiss.

“Mary Long will be there. I found out yesterday. A last minute acceptance. I told Billy not to allow it but… she’s a good ally to have. At least for Stark.”

Rio raised her brows at this piece of information, all teasing now gone from her face as she watched Agatha closely, “You know I’ve-…”

“I know. She’s the one I heard about you from.”

Rio nodded slowly and dropped her gaze to take Agatha’s hand, “She won’t say anything. For all intents and purposes she’s a happily married mother of two.”

“Was it often? Your seeing her?”

“Maybe half a dozen times. It was only ever for sex.”

Rio looked back up then and saw the usual glint of jealousy in Agatha’s gaze. A few times now Agatha had asked Rio about her old clients and every time she’d looked reticent, as if against her better wishes she was torturing herself with the knowledge and memory of Rio’s old job. It was self-flagellation. But Rio always shut it down.

“What did she want?”

Rio sighed quietly and shook her head, “I’m not telling you that. There’s no reason for you to know.”

Agatha nodded as if she had known that would be the response but clearly decided to drop it and instead leant back fully against the side of the car.

“Well, knowledge is power.”

“And how will knowing what she likes to do in bed help you in this case?”

Agatha shrugged a little and Rio felt safe to continue this line of conversation because Agatha’s lips twitched into a small smile, “I can announce that whatever she did with you I’ve done it better. And more besides.”

Rio hummed and shuffled back along the bench to reflect Agatha’s position on the other side, “Yeah? What makes you so sure?”

Agatha’s gaze narrowed and she raised her chin a little, “Because I know I’m the best.”

“Is that right?”

“Careful, Vidal. Keep pushing it and I’ll traumatise poor Jimmy right here, right now.”

Rio laughed and shook her head, “You are the best. Is that what you want to hear?”

“All day. Every day.”

“Mmhm. Well maybe I’ll just tattoo it across my stomach so next time you’re down there you can get a constant reminder.”

“Agatha,” Agatha corrected with a gentle nip to Rio’s pulse point that made her squirm with desire.

“Shut. Up.”

“Of course.”

But Natasha was her best friend and Natasha had promised to be there so Rio focused on that. What she knew to be true. Not what she hoped wasn’t.

She let herself into Natasha’s apartment with the key she had on the little bundle from her bag and sucked in a sharp breath as the familiar scent of the little apartment filled her lungs.

The small space was open plan, a little larger than her own Washington Heights apartment, with one big, long space as a living area, framed one side by inbuilt bookshelves and on the other by a door to a bathroom, an open kitchen, and a large arched entranceway to the bedroom that faced the small area where Natasha now sat in one armchair, facing Rio, looking across the space at her with a soft expression.

“You lost weight.”

“No I didn’t.”

“Your hair’s shorter.”

“No it’s not.”

“What’s differ-…?”

But then shrewd green eyes fell to Rio’s left hand that sat by her hip and they widened briefly, imperceptibly. But Rio knew Natasha. She knew her tells.

“When did that happen?”

Rio took steps forward until she was directly in front of Natasha’s chair and bent down to kiss her cheek, ignoring that Natasha’s hands had flown immediately to take Rio’s hand and examine the piece of jewellery she found so offensive.

“And you’re telling me now?”

“You’ve never been too busy for me.”

“You started your new life. I figured you didn’t need me-…”

“Natasha you are my family. I will always need you. Do you know how much I’ve missed you?”

Natasha remained silent for a while before she sat back in her chair a little and splayed her fingers out where they sat on the arms.

“Regretting moving?”

“No. Regretting that my best friend doesn’t want to support me.”

Natasha cleared her throat, clearly having this kept entirely to herself this whole time had taken its toll and she seemed suddenly animated, desperate to get it off her chest.

“I told you what I’d heard about Abigail. I followed that trail. And it led me, it led me to Wanda, to Sokovia. That’s where I was at Christmas.”

“Has Agatha told you what she’s doing?”

“That isn’t what we’re discussing.”

“And yet you’re marrying her and chastising me.”

“This isn’t about you versus Agatha.”

“Isn’t it?”

“It doesn’t have to be. I can’t have a life with her and a life with you.”

“Then you’re dropping me.”

“No!” Rio’s head snapped up and she looked up to see devastation flicker across Natasha’s features, her fingers now curling in on themselves to get a grip on her own emotions.

“Natasha.” She leant more forward, her body twitching for her to go to Natasha and envelope her even as her words became harsher, more desperate. “You haven’t even tried with Agatha. “Why everyone decided I was too fragile or too stupid to be let in, I have no idea.”

She began to pace. An unfortunate habit she’d picked up from living with a very dramatic woman.

But her mind was running away with itself even as her feet marched up and down the little space between the two chairs in the makeshift living space Natasha had made for herself.

“Vse slozhno.” It’s complicated.

“Too complicated for little old me?”

Rio spat back, spinning halfway through her movement away from Natasha to round on her.

“Sit down, Rio.”

“No. No. You can’t tell me what to do. Tell me what’s going on. Why are you and Agatha avoiding the truth?”

Natasha pursed her lips slightly and her gaze fell from Rio’s furious face to the hand that curled into a fist, emphasising the impressive diamond that sat proud on her finger. The sight of it, the promise that it held, caused Natasha to suck in a sharp breath before she spoke again, her voice low, steady:

“No. That cannot be right.”

Natasha rolled her shoulders in a half-shrug and dropped her gaze then to her fingers tapping at the arms of her chair. “I told you I’d been busy.”

“I don’t know the depths of it. I don’t know a lot, actually. But Wanda’s been working with Abigail. Feeding secrets. Selling stories.”

“She was married to her.”

“Yes.”

Rio shook her head slightly and watched but didn’t see as Natasha moved from her chair for the first time, and went to stop just before her. “Yes.”

“Natasha.”

Rio blinked and saw reflected in green eyes the truth that she’d just realised.

“Agatha wouldn’t.”

“Okay.”

“I’m serious.”

“Okay.”

“She wouldn’t.”

“Don’t you think it’s suspicious that she’s so hellbent on getting Wanda what she wants?”

“That’s not-…”

“It is.”

“Bullshit.” Rio snapped so viciously she almost gave herself whiplash. But she was sure. Certain. Agatha wouldn’t.

“You’re just saying this because-…”

“Because?”

“Because…” Rio faltered, her eyes darting across the face she knew so well, the face she’d grown up with and had loved for years.

The words were on the tip of her tongue but they tasted like bile, venomous and irrevocable.

They tumbled from Rio’s lips like thunder in the night.

“Because you’re in love with me.”

Chapter End Notes

👀

The Vows

Chapter Summary

Rio finally gets some answers and pushes for some promises.

Chapter Notes

Idk man this could go either way

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Because you’re in love with me.”

Natasha stood stockstill in front of her, staring at her with an unreadable expression, her fingers twisting in the fabric of her shirt so much that Rio felt the fibres strain against her back as she pulled it forwards.

Natasha didn’t blink.

But then, unexpectedly, she laughed.

A deep, throaty laugh that lasted not long enough to be true but instead a short sharp burst of ridicule aimed Rio’s way.

And Rio felt shame run through her like a hot knife.

“Agatha put you up to this. She got in your head.”

Rio scoffed but couldn’t look at Natasha and instead turned her face away, gritting her teeth as she tried to calm herself down, not focus on the mortification she was currently feeling.

“I am jealous. I’ll admit that. But I won’t apologise for it. I’ve been looking out for you almost half your life. I know you better than anyone.”

“Tasha,” Rio pleaded softly, finally turning to gaze at her best friend with a deep frown and an unconscious pout, pushing her hands away from her.

Natasha relinquished her hold, but reluctantly.

“Do you want me to be in love with you? Would it make all this easier?”

“Of course not.”

“Does she want me to be in love with you? To have a rival? To have a duel for your honour?”

Rio sighed in a mix of exasperation and embarrassment, walking away from Natasha to sit back down and returning her head to her hands and her elbows on her knees. Deflated. Depleted.

They were both silent for a turn, both thinking hard about what being in love with the other might mean for the future of their relationship. In both women even the concept of it all too much to bear.

“Look,” Natasha started slowly, stepping towards Rio again until she could sit down on the other chair, not once taking her eyes off of the Latina, though the other woman was avoiding her gaze. “Maybe for a year or two I had a crush. I found you… appealing.”

And I do love you. More than anyone. The only people that ever came close to you were your parents. Maria and Luis were…” she stopped then and dropped her gaze down to the floor, her voice lowering again, “I’m not in love with you. But I am jealous. It’s always been just us two and now… now I have to share you with a woman I don’t like and I don’t trust.”

“I need to go home.”

She was a boiling pot that was spilling over.

“No.” Rio snapped, pushing Natasha’s hands away forcefully and ripping her own from the hold she had on her. “She is my home. And you have chosen to not be a part of my life for the past few weeks and now you’re accusing her-…”

The very idea that it would all be because Agatha was trying to protect her and ignoring the danger she was throwing herself infront of made her want to vomit. The small fire of anger that had been smouldering in her chest at Natasha’s refusal to speak to her these past few weeks had become a five-alarm fury, with Agatha’s downfall the kindling that she needed to set it aflame.

The solid nature of it grounded her. “Apparently not.”

“I do love you,” Natasha said softly, her lips twitching into a soft, earnest smile, “Just not in the way Agatha’s afraid of.”

Sighing softly and tilting her head, Rio watched Natasha for a while, “Don’t love me enough to kill for me.”

“No promises.”

Rio shouldered her bag and bit down on her lip, shooting Natasha one last look before she left.

Of what she’d say when Rio insisted she drop whatever plans she had for Wanda. Of what Agatha would say if she gave her an ultimatum.

Would she give her one? Could she?

However she thought to play it the one thing she couldn’t shake was that Wanda had her claws in them both. Either Rio stood by and let Agatha risk her safety to get Wanda or she told Agatha ‘enough’ and walked away but kept Agatha safe. Neither was a good option. Neither let her keep Agatha.

The familiar, welcome scent of home, of Agatha, filled her lungs and she lingered so long in the hall that Agatha appeared before her, confused as to who had entered her apartment and not announced themselves and then suddenly concerned that it was Rio, looking pale and a little frightened.

“Honey,” Agatha murmured quickly, moving over to take Rio’s bag and place it down, leaning around her to close the door over her shoulder.

“Rio, what’s wrong? What happened? Did Natasha…?”

These pieces of Agatha’s evening without her made her yearn for this to be over, so that in every evening to come Rio could be part of this vignette.

“No, no. It’s not good enough anymore. Natasha told me what she’s doing. That she’s selling information to the highest bidder. That she’s working with Abigail. Do you know how dangerous it is to get involved with that?”

Agatha’s panicked look morphed into confusion, and then anger, “Natasha told you that? She shouldn’t have done.”

“Well someone had to!” Rio shouted suddenly, “Considering the woman I’m about to marry didn’t feel it necessary to tell me that her ex-wife was committing treason!”

Agatha dropped her gaze for a second and slowly stood, her hands turning into fists at her side. “And you think I’ve had something to do with-…”

“No.” Rio clenched her jaw and stepped in to fist Agatha’s sweater in her hands, jostling the glasses that hung there. “No. But I think she’ll try and drag you down with her anyway if you try to get involved.”

Blue eyes flickered up to scan over Rio’s face for any sign of a lie but found none and she lifted her chin slightly as she spoke again, “Natasha needs to stay out of it.”

“You need to stay out of it.”

Agatha laughed derisively and turned her head away even as Rio stepped closer into her and reached for her cheek, “Agatha. I’m not asking anymore. I’m telling you. You need to step away. I can’t lose you.”

Something changed then in the room, a spark of something flickered out and Rio felt it in the way Agatha’s body relaxed, in the way her hands released their hold at her sides, in the way she turned her head to match Rio’s gaze.

“Once I take out Wanda we will be safe to-…”

“No,” Rio said softly, her voice catching a little in her throat as she swallowed, “I feel safe when I have you with me. If you pursue this you are risking that. You are wilfully making me feel unsafe and scared and it’s because you’re stubborn and angry and I understand that but I am telling you that I will not forgive you if you let her take you away from me.”

“You don’t understand. Natasha has no business telling you-…”

“Natasha is my best friend.”

“Yeah? Not from where I’m standing. She’s barely spoken to you since you moved in. She’s doing this to-…”

“Agatha,” Rio said more forcefully this time, watching as Agatha knocked back whatever expensive amber liquid she’d just poured herself.

“Do you not see how dangerous this is? How reckless?”

“It’ll keep her away from you. Keep you safe.”

Agatha still hadn’t turned around, was now pouring herself another glass and then grabbed another to fill that up too.

“I will not stand back whilst you throw yourself to the lions in the name of protecting me. If people find out what I used to do, fine. If people-…”

“People is the problem,” Agatha said coolly, her voice now purposefully low and steady where Rio’s was getting progressively louder.

“Wanda knows a lot of people who could have you hurt and I-…”

Rio shook her head and threw her hands out, “Listen to yourself! If she knows people who would come after me then think about what she’d do to you!”

Agatha just shook her head again and turned around, holding out one crystal glass to Rio with an exceptionally large pour.

“Have a drink. It’ll calm you down.”

But Agatha should have known these were the wrong words to say to Rio. They were like gasoline on a dumpster fire.

And Rio drank it down with a thirst she didn’t know she had, with an overwhelming desire to explode, and so she did.

“YOU CANNOT WIN THIS! You cannot just sweep her away! You are putting yourself in so much danger and are risking what we have for some crackpot idea that you can beat Wanda when it actually doesn’t fucking matter anymore! Because we matter. Not her. Us. All I want is you. Why can’t you see that?!”

If the residents of Jane Street had thought they’d heard yelling a few months ago emanating from Number 9 then they were sure that they heard it this night. The quiet little street in Manhattan was shaken by the desperate yells of a desperate woman and curtains twitched as Rio unleashed at Agatha, unable to temper her desperation any longer.

Agatha stood in silence, her eyes wide and her lips parted in stunned surprise at the unusually volatile scene before her. Of all the arguments they’d ever had… Rio had never shouted like this. She’d never shouted like this at anyone. And certainly not at Agatha.

But Rio returned to herself then and even as her voice cracked and her hands shook she watched the words wash over the woman before her, crashing into her like a freight train.

Agatha swallowed and turned around again, placing the two glasses on the side as she processed Rio’s thunder.

Rio’s body was shaking, from either adrenaline or fear, she didn’t know. She could no longer compute anything. The only thing she was certain of was that Agatha wasn’t going to give in and she would have to watch as she was dragged down by this scarlet-haired witch.

The shaking turned into sobbing and unable to stop herself, Rio collapsed into herself, squatting down slowly and burying her face in her hands to preserve what very little dignity she had left.

But no sooner had she done so than strong hands were against her back and wrists and Agatha was back against her, pulling her up and pressing her into herself. Rio wasn’t in her body anymore but somehow her body knew what to do, allowing itself to be jostled and moved, lifted and held by the familiar touch of Agatha Harkness.

Soft lips brushed over her hair as Agatha had settled Rio into her lap, cradling her against her with a tender ferocity that Rio had grown accustomed to and was so terrified of losing.

Rio’s breathing was slow to even out but was guided to its normal rhythm by Agatha’s soft touches and the gentle reassurances breathed out against her temple.

”It’s okay. You’re okay. I have you.”

Slowly, almost reluctantly, when she felt she could stand it, she pulled away and blinked down at the woman before her, watching as silent tears marred her face too.

“Please,” she whispered, “Please don’t.”

And to Rio’s great relief and surprise, Agatha nodded.

“Okay.”

Frowning in confusion, and pulling back more to shift and raise up on her knees, Rio cupped the face she loved so much and brushed her thumbs over wet cheeks. “Okay?”

“Just,” Agatha began softly, so softly that Rio’s heart ached for the woman who seemed to have shrunk before her, holding Rio so tightly and gazing up at her like she was about to lose her. “Just don’t leave me, okay? I couldn’t handle it.”

“Leave you?”

Agatha swallowed thickly and blue eyes swirled with unspoken fears as she dropped her gaze from Rio’s face and focused on her chest as her hands moved to hold her above her ribs, clutching the fabric there, “I can be good. I can protect you. I can-…”

Her words dissolved into a soft sob and she closed her eyes tightly as Rio’s whole world crashed down around her.

It wasn’t about Wanda. It was about proving herself to Rio. Proving herself worthy.

“I-…”

In all the ways Rio thought this conversation might go, this was not one of them.

She’d thought that Agatha might scream, that she might shout and insist what she was doing was right and the only way. She’d thought that they might end the night not speaking or that they’d be up until morning arguing the point.

But she’d never envisioned Agatha collapsing in on herself before her eyes, vulnerable and small before her.

A fury unlike the one she’d been in not minutes ago alighted in her chest. This fury was deeper, more guttural. And it was directed at everyone in Agatha’s life who hadn’t loved her the way she deserved. Everyone who had taken advantage. Everyone who had failed her.

And it was directed at herself.

For all the missteps she’d made in their relationship that meant that Agatha hadn’t yet found true comfort in her. For the time it had taken her to give up her job even though she knew it hurt Agatha. For her inability to fix everything about her past, and to keep Agatha safe from her demons.

“Agatha,” Rio uttered desperately, continuing to brush away fresh tears that fell silently down her fiancée’s cheeks, “You are everything I’ve ever wanted and everything I thought I could never have.”

Agatha’s lips parted in a soft gasp and she dared to look up again then, her brow furrowing as if she didn’t believe Rio, but her hands twisted in the fabric of her shirt and Rio knew she wanted her closer. She leant down and adjusted herself in Agatha’s lap, resting their foreheads together and tasted the rich oaky whisky on Agatha’s breath.

“My love,” Rio uttered, leaning in to brush their lips together, “The safest I ever feel is in your arms. Don’t take that away from me. Please.”

Agatha only nodded, her breathing slowing down now as she leant up into Rio properly, in a salty, desperate promise.

When they both pulled up for air, still barely centimetres apart, Agatha spoke again: “I can’t stand that you’re vulnerable because of me. Because of her. Because of my choices… my weakness.”

“You’re not weak,” Rio corrected gently, pulling back slightly so she could reach down and stretch her t-shirt to the max to brush the fabric over Agatha’s face, wiping the residue of tears from her cheeks, “You fell in love and she…”

“It wasn’t love,” Agatha said quickly, shaking her head once Rio was done with her ministrations, “I know that now. It wasn’t this. It was a desire to be loved and I thought she… she convinced me she did.”

Rio blew out a soft breath and watched as Agatha’s eyes fluttered slowly, her fingers twitched across her ribs, “I need you to know that all I ever want is you. Not you trying to protect me. Not you throwing yourself at getting rid of her, thinking it will keep me safe, just you. Right here. I want to go to sleep with you every night and I want to wake up with you every morning.”

Agatha bit down on her lower lip and Rio raised her thumb to pull it free from her teeth’s hold, replacing her thumb soon with her own lips. Agatha returned the kiss and then moved to kiss Rio’s cheek, her other cheek, her nose, “Okay,” she said quietly, “Let’s go away. Just you and me.”

“You’ll quit the campaign? Drop your plans for Wanda?”

Agatha shifted and moved her hands down to Rio’s hips to pull them closer to her own and Rio sighed, feeling a wave of relief wash over her like no other as Agatha said: “If it’s a choice between that and making you feel less safe, making you… yes. Okay.”

Rio’s lips twitched at the sides but her body, her body shook a little from a sudden, residual tension that had settled into her bones. She skimmed her fingers over Agatha’s cheekbone and whispered reverently, “Thank you.”

The older woman before her just nodded and Rio saw hesitation in her eyes, her lips parting as if she were weighing something up before she spoke again. “And… Natasha? How did… how did that go?”

Rio sighed softly and replaced her fingers against Agatha’s cheek with a soft kiss before she pulled away to speak again, “She went to Sokovia at Christmas, following on some whispers she’d heard about Abigail and Wanda. And she threatened to hire a hitman to take her out but I-…”

“Surpringly easy to do,” Agatha muttered, her eyes darting up to catch Rio’s gaze again.

“You wouldn’t.”

“I considered it.”

Rio rolled her eyes and placed her head in her hands as she considered what it was about her that made the two women she loved most in the world be the type of women who would consider hiring a hitman.

“That is so insane I can’t even-…”

But Agatha was prying her hands away from her face and smiling just a little, “It’s not sexy? Me murdering someone for you?”

“That is…” but Rio couldn’t deny the way her stomach flipped at the thought of Agatha having such power, such control, that she could and would simply say the word and someone would be gone. For her.

She cleared her throat, even as Agatha’s soft smile turned into a smirk, a sure sign she’d been caught out and an even bigger sign that Agatha was beginning to relax again.

“No. No it isn’t.”

Agatha quirked a brow but chose not to say anything as she dropped her gaze to where she held Rio’s hips again, “And did you ask her if-…?”

“Yes,” Rio said with a heavy sigh, raising Agatha’s chin to look her in the eye again. She saw in blue eyes that same hesitation from earlier, that same fear. “She’s not in love with me. But she did admit she was jealous and she’s still suspicious of you.”

Agatha went to respond but Rio interrupted her quickly, “I told her she needed to get to know you. To make an effort. And she promised she would.”

Agatha nodded once and dropped her gaze again, even when Rio still held her chin.

“Will you try too?”

A beat passed where Rio thought Agatha might deny her request, might change the subject, or worse, but she nodded slowly, looking back up to Rio again, “Okay.”

Rio leant in to capture the promise on her lips and slipped her hands back to cradle Agatha’s head, tangled herself in the messy bun that Agatha had thrown up the moment she’d arrived home. Agatha hesitated only for a second before she returned the kiss and Rio shivered again when she felt Agatha’s tongue cautiously, almost politely brush against her lower lip.

“I’m so in love with you, Rio Vidal. I will spend the rest of my life trying to be good enough for-…”

“Agatha,” Rio murmured softly, her fingers twitching in Agatha’s hold, “You are good enough. Too good for me.”

Agatha just shook her head and placed Rio’s hands to her own neck, holding them there so that she could release them and hold Rio’s hips again, “I wanted you and then I loved you and now I… I’ll do whatever to keep you.”

Large brown eyes fluttered closed and Rio pursed her lips together as she fought off the tears that threatened to keep falling, focusing instead on the gentle pressure at her hips, the soft breaths against her cheek as Agatha leant in again, “Come to bed. It’s been a while since I’ve held you.”

Another shiver went through Rio’s body at this request and she could only nod as she allowed Agatha to help her stand and direct her with a soft but confident pressure on her lower back into the bedroom.

The night sky outside the large window was already pitch black but Agatha went to close the shutters to envelope the room in the kind of moody light that would usually relax Rio’s nervous system.

But it was Agatha’s hands against her that helped this time, strong and steady as she removed her shirt and unzipped her jeans. In any other circumstance of Agatha removing her clothes like this, Rio would have been panting and desperate at the subtle dominance Agatha was exhibiting but all she could think about was how lucky she was that Agatha was still here, that she’d listened, and that she would hold her.
